title: 112_s3196
content: The Act titled "National Women's High-Growth Business Bipartisan Task Force Act of 2012" establishes the National Women's High-Growth Business Bipartisan Task Force, defining key terms such as "Administration" and "Task Force." The National Women's High-Growth Business Bipartisan Task Force is established to provide advice and recommendations to the Administrator, Congress, the President, and other federal departments. It consists of 15 members, including small business owners controlled by women and individuals with expertise in women's business research and entrepreneurship. The National Women's High-Growth Business Bipartisan Task Force consists of 15 members, including small business owners controlled by women and individuals with expertise in women's business research and entrepreneurship. Members are appointed by various Senate and House committees, representing women's business organizations. The National Women's High-Growth Business Bipartisan Task Force comprises 15 members, including small business owners controlled by women and experts in women's business research and entrepreneurship. Members are appointed by Senate and House committees, with geographic considerations taken into account. The initial members must be appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The National Women's High-Growth Business Bipartisan Task Force consists of 15 members, with a focus on geographic representation and political diversity. Members elect a Chairperson, serve 3-year terms, and fill vacancies as needed. The National Women's High-Growth Business Bipartisan Task Force consists of 15 members serving 3-year terms. Initial appointees have varying term lengths of 4 or 5 years. The National Women's High-Growth Business Bipartisan Task Force consists of 15 members serving 3-year terms. Vacancies must be filled within 30 days, and appointees cannot hold federal employment, except under certain conditions. The National Women's High-Growth Business Bipartisan Task Force consists of 15 members serving 3-year terms. Members serve without compensation but are reimbursed for travel expenses. The Task Force reviews and monitors plans affecting small businesses owned by women and advises on improving coordination between public and private sector programs. It also monitors and promotes federal department programs supporting small business development. The National Women's High-Growth Business Bipartisan Task Force advises federal departments on promoting startups and high-growth small businesses owned by women. They also examine the link between women entrepreneurs and intellectual property. The National Women's High-Growth Business Bipartisan Task Force focuses on the number of patents, trademarks, and copyrights granted to women, as well as the challenges faced by women-owned high-growth small businesses in obtaining and enforcing intellectual property rights. The Task Force has the power to hold hearings, establish task groups, request information from federal agencies, and use the United States mails for communication. The National Women's High-Growth Business Bipartisan Task Force has the authority to meet at least three times a year, accept gifts, and involve representatives from Federal agencies in its meetings. The Task Force encourages participation from Federal agency representatives in meetings, who can serve as resources but cannot vote. Meetings are typically held at the Administration's headquarters unless agreed otherwise. The Administrator provides necessary meeting facilities and support. The Task Force must submit reports within 30 days after each fiscal year. The Task Force must submit reports to the President and relevant committees within 30 days after each fiscal year, detailing their activities, findings, recommendations, and suggestions for promoting intellectual property rights for women-owned small businesses. The Task Force is required to submit reports on promoting intellectual property rights for women-owned small businesses, including legislative and administrative actions. The reports must include any dissenting views of the Administrator and minutes of Task Force meetings. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy must also conduct studies at least twice a year. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy, in consultation with the Task Force, conducts biannual studies on issues important to small businesses owned by women. The topics of the studies are determined by the Task Force and focus on federal contracts awarded to women-owned small businesses. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy, in consultation with the Task Force, conducts biannual studies on issues important to small businesses owned by women. This includes topics such as access to credit, intellectual property rights, and any other relevant issues identified by the Task Force. The Chief Counsel may contract with a public or private entity for conducting these studies. The Chief Counsel is also responsible for reporting on the findings of these studies. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy conducts biannual studies on issues important to small businesses owned by women, including access to credit and intellectual property rights. They may contract with a public or private entity for these studies and report the findings to relevant committees. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Task Force. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy conducts biannual studies on issues important to small businesses owned by women, including access to credit and intellectual property rights. They may contract with a public or private entity for these studies and report the findings to relevant committees. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Task Force. REPEAL. The Interagency Committee on Women's Business Enterprise and the National Women's Business Council must submit reports to the President and relevant committees within 90 days of this Act. The Women's Business Ownership Act of 1988 is repealed. The Women's Business Ownership Act of 1988 (15 U.S.C. 631 note) is repealed, and technical amendments are made to the Small Business Act (15 U.S.C. 631 et seq.) to remove references to the repealed act. The Women's Business Ownership Act of 1988 is repealed, and amendments are made to the Small Business Act to remove references to the repealed act. The amendments made by subsections (b) and (c) shall take effect 90 days after the date of enactment of this Act.
